I was trying to aerobrake the ship pictured below into a lower orbit. Am I correct that, in 1.0, aerobraking large ships is quite tedious?

It would get on the edge of overheating at ~43km and the amount of dV lost was quite small. It would have taken dozens of passes to do what I wanted.

Also, I'm not sure why the middle tier of fuel tanks were the ones that got the hottest? I would have thought it would be the engines or the projecting RCS thrusters.

Edited July 8, 2015 by davidpsummers

I was trying to aerobrake the ship pictured below into a lower orbit. Am I correct that, in 1.0, aerobraking large ships is quite tedious?

It would get on the edge of overheating at ~43km and the amount of dV lost was quite small. It would have taken dozens of passes to do what I wanted.

It takes some attention to detail, but it's not too bad. When you were aerobraking, what attitude did you use? One thing that can help is to try to maximize your drag, e.g. flying sideways rather than engines-first, at least until the heating gets up to the point where you need to go engines-first so that your more temperature-sensitive components don't get fried.

I highly recommend airbrakes, they're extraordinarily effective. Cheap, light, convenient radial attachment, come with their own built-in hotkey. They can slow you down significantly while you're still way up high, and have the added advantage that you can turn them on/off while you're aerobraking. This makes it less touchy (i.e. you're not totally committed at the time you choose periapsis-- if you have an "oh crap, my periapsis is too low" moment, just ease up on the brakes).

Also, I'm not sure why the middle tier of fuel tanks were the ones that got the hottest? I would have thought it would be the engines or the projecting RCS thrusters.

Hm, that is a a bit odd... perhaps the upper tanks were a lot emptier, and therefore had less thermal mass and heated up faster?

I came in with a periapsis of ~43km. (Think it was 42.6km, might have been 43.6). Couldn't have taken much more heating and only lowered my apoapsis from 46,000 km to 20,000 km. (About 60m/s by my reckoning).

A smaller ship (Midsized Rockomax tank, Poodle engine, and a three man capsule). Got down to 37 km and lost about 240 m/s. But it also was mostly empty in fuel and smaller (less weight for cross section area) so I figure it just works better for smaller craft.

One the ship pictured, the middle tanks were full.
